FacilityName: Bureau Service Co. d/b/a Ag View FS, Inc. - Ohio
ParentCompanyName: Bureau Service Co. d/b/a Ag View FS, Inc.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.



The management and employees of Bureau Service Company are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Ohio Fire Department, Bureau County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2.  The stationary source and the regulated substance handled.



The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 28462 2300 East Street, Ohio, IL  61349, is the storage and distribution of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of (2) 18,000 gallon storage tanks, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 500,000 pounds; this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.



3.  The accidental release prevention program.



This facility complies with EPA'S Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state and codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of Title 8 Illinois Administrative Code 215: Anhydrous Ammonia, Low Pressure Nitrogen Solutions, Equipment, Containers, and Storage Facilities, based upon the Compressed Gas Associations (CGA'S) "American National Standard Safety Requirements or the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" (6th edition) , commonly referred to as "ANSI/CGA G-2.1 2014", and the standards of the U.S. Occupational and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations

and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program. 



4.  Five year accident history.



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:

* Have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor

* To our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5.  The Emergency Response Program.



The facility has:

* A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

* Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



In the event of emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Ohio Fire Department and Bureau County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.



6.  Planned changes to improve safety.



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
